attr.fort.name: Chittorgarh Fort
attr.fort.desc: A UNESCO World Heritage Site and the largest fort in India. A symbol of resilience and architectural brilliance.
attr.padmini.name: Padmini Palace
attr.padmini.desc: A legendary palace surrounded by water, famous for the bravery of Rani Padmini. A masterpiece of architectural grace.
attr.bassi.name: Bassi Wildlife Sanctuary
attr.bassi.desc: A haven for nature lovers, home to panthers, wild boars, and migratory birds.
attr.temple.name: Sanwariaji Temple
attr.temple.desc: Dedicated to Lord Krishna, this temple is a significant pilgrimage site known for its grandeur.
attr.vijay.name: Vijay Stambh (Victory Tower)
attr.vijay.desc: Built by Rana Kumbha to commemorate his victory over Mahmud Khilji. A 9-story marvel.
attr.kirti.name: Kirti Stambha (Tower of Fame)
attr.kirti.desc: A 12th-century tower dedicated to Adinath, the first Jain Tirthankara. A masterpiece of Solanki architectural style.
attr.kalika.name: Kalika Mata Temple
attr.kalika.desc: Originally a Sun Temple built in the 8th century, dedicated to Goddess Bhadrakali.
attr.jain.name: Sattavis Jain Temples
attr.jain.desc: A group of 27 ancient Jain temples showcasing intricate carvings and spiritual serenity.
attr.gaumukh.name: Gaumukh Reservoir
attr.gaumukh.desc: A sacred water tank shaped like a cow's mouth, located near the Vijay Stambh.
attr.fateh.name: Fateh Prakash Palace
attr.fateh.desc: A magnificent palace built by Rana Fateh Singh, now a museum showcasing royal artifacts and history.
attr.menal.name: Menal Waterfall & Temple
attr.menal.desc: A stunning waterfall complex with 11th-century temples, often called the 'Mini Khajuraho' of Rajasthan.
attr.meera.name: Meera Bai Temple
attr.meera.desc: Dedicated to the mystic poet-saint Meera Bai, this temple is a symbol of devotion and love for Lord Krishna.
attr.ratan.name: Ratan Singh Palace
attr.ratan.desc: Overlooking the Ratneshwar Talab, this palace offers a glimpse into the royal lifestyle of the Mewar rulers.
attr.kumbha_palace.name: Rana Kumbha Palace
attr.kumbha_palace.desc: The oldest and largest palace in the fort, associated with the legend of Rani Padmini's Jauhar.
attr.kumbha_shyam.name: Kumbha Shyam Temple
attr.kumbha_shyam.desc: Built by Rana Kumbha, this temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and features unique Indo-Aryan architecture.
attr.light.name: Light & Sound Show
attr.light.desc: A mesmerizing evening show narrating the history of Chittorgarh Fort.
chron.hero.title: The Mewar Chronicles
chron.hero.sub: Legends of Sacrifice, Valour, and Devotion
legend.padmini.title: Rani Padmini
legend.padmini.subtitle: The Saga of Grace and Sacrifice
legend.padmini.desc: Known for her ethereal beauty and sharp intellect, Rani Padmini is a symbol of supreme sacrifice. To protect the honour of Chittorgarh from the siege of Alauddin Khalji, she led the heroic 'Jauhar' along with thousands of brave women, a tale that still echoes in the fort's wind.
legend.pratap.title: Maharana Pratap
legend.pratap.subtitle: The Unyielding Spirit
legend.pratap.desc: The lion of Mewar who never bowed to the Mughal Empire. Along with his legendary horse Chetak, he fought for the freedom of his land in the battle of Haldighati. His life was a testament to the belief that liberty is worth more than a golden throne.
legend.panna.title: Panna Dhai
legend.panna.subtitle: The Ultimate Sacrifice
legend.panna.desc: A nursemaid like no other, who sacrificed her own son, Chandan, to save the infant Prince Udai Singh from an assassin. Her unwavering loyalty ensured the continuation of the Mewar dynasty, proving that some bonds are deeper than blood.
legend.meera.title: Meera Bai
legend.meera.subtitle: The Devotion of the Soul
legend.meera.desc: A princess who renounced royal luxuries for the love of Lord Krishna. Her soulful bhajans and fearless devotion redefined spirituality, reminding the world that the greatest strength lies in pure, unshakeable love.
chron.footer.aiNote: The cinematic illustrations in this chronicle were reimagined using advanced Artificial Intelligence to visualize the timeless legends of Mewar.
chron.footer.heritage: Chittorgarh: Where history is etched in stone and soul.

fact.title: Did You Know?
fact.1: Chittorgarh Fort is the largest fort complex in India and Asia, sprawling over 700 acres.
fact.2: The fort originally had 84 water bodies, including ponds, wells, and stepwells.
fact.3: Vijay Stambh (Tower of Victory) features 157 narrow steps to reach the 9th floor.
fact.4: The fort was recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2013 for its architectural grandeur.
fact.5: Meera Bai, the legendary poet-saint and devotee of Lord Krishna, resided within these fort walls.
fact.6: The fort's history dates back to the 7th century, originally built by the Maurya Dynasty.
fact.7: There are 7 massive gateways (Pols) to enter the citadel, each with its own historical significance.
fact.8: Rani Padmini's Palace is uniquely built amidst a beautiful lotus pool.
fact.9: Kirti Stambh (Tower of Fame) is a 12th-century tower dedicated to the first Jain Tirthankara, Adinath.
fact.10: The Gaumukh Reservoir is a sacred water body fed by a spring that flows from a carved cow's mouth.
